description:
Founded in 1881 as the world’s first collegiate business school, the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania remains guided by Joseph Wharton’s original vision: using analytical expertise to produce well-rounded leaders to drive societal progress. As we continue our quest for positive global impact, the Wharton Way serves as our philosophical North Star with three areas of focus – elevating our research impact, innovating through our pedagogy, and collaborating across disciplines and divides.

With a standing faculty of 241 renowned professors, Wharton has 5,000+ students across four degree programs: undergraduate, MBA, executive MBA, and doctoral. Each year 13,000+ professionals from around the world advance their careers through Wharton Executive Education’s individual, company-customized, and online programs – with 200,000+ others earning certificates from Wharton Online since 2015. More than 104,000 Wharton alumni form a powerful global network of leaders who transform business every day.

Thank you to everyone who joined us for the first installment of Policies that Work, a new series exploring the national policies shaping America!

In a discussion moderated by Senior Vice Dean Joao Gomes, Profs. Jeremy Siegel and Kent Smetters – Faculty Director of the Penn Wharton Budget Model – explored the intricate relationship between national debt and economic stability, growth, and the financial well-being of individuals.

By exploring how federal borrowing impacts interest rates, inflation, and future fiscal policies, you will gain a clearer understanding of what the rising debt in the U.S. means for the economy at large — and your personal finances.

Learn more about the series and upcoming events: whr.tn/policiesthatwork

From the Schuylkill River to the Han River. 🇰🇷 Cosette Burrese (W'26), a #WhartonUndergrad in the Huntsman Program, traveled to Seoul, South Korea this summer as part of the University of Pennsylvania's Global Research & Internship Program.

Cosette shares her experience interning in Seoul's media industry and exploring the city's cultural offerings, including sampling traditional cuisine and even taking a K-Pop dance class at the famous 1Million Dance Studio: https://whr.tn/4h3rfWk

“Stepping out of my comfort zone has been a recurring theme during my stay here,” Cosette writes. “Whether it's participating in a spontaneous karaoke session with colleagues or navigating the bustling streets and foreign transit system, each experience has helped me grow and adapt.”

The Wharton AI & Analytics Initiative’s second annual Business & Generative AI Workshop brought more than 150 academics and industry researchers to our San Francisco campus last month: https://whr.tn/4hhdseD

Over the course of two days, participants networked and explored innovative ideas and insights into the transformative potential of generative AI on business models, industries, and global economies.

Hosted by AI at Wharton Faculty Co-Directors Kartik Hosanagar and Stefano Puntoni, as well as Prof. Lynn Wu, the workshop featured keynotes from Stanford Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI) Senior Fellow Erik Brynjolfsson and Databricks CIO Naveen Zutshi as well as sessions led by a diverse range of researchers and industry experts.

It also featured a conversation between Dean Erika H. James and #WhartonGrad James Crowley (W’96), Accenture’s Global Products Industry Practices Chair.

We're excited to introduce Leading an AI-Powered Future, a groundbreaking new six-week live online program designed in collaboration with Reid Hoffman, Co-Founder of LinkedIn and thought leader in AI transformation.

This program will immerse senior executives in the immense potential of #AI to reshape business, leadership, and society. Anchored by insights from Hoffman’s forthcoming book, ‘Superagency’, participants will gain the tools to:

💡 Embrace the opportunities AI presents
💡 Lead effectively in AI-driven environments
💡 Understand the ethical responsibilities of AI integration

Hoffman will personally lead the inaugural session, with subsequent weeks taught by top faculty from the Wharton AI & Analytics Initiative including Stefano Puntoni, Ethan Mollick, Lynn Wu, Nicolaj Siggelkow, and Christian Terwiesch.

This program is ideal for senior executives ready to drive AI-powered transformation within their organizations. Whether you're an AI veteran or just getting started, this program will equip you with the leadership frameworks to fully harness the future of AI.

🔗 Learn more and apply today: https://whr.tn/3AalBB6

🎃 During the fall, it can seem like pumpkin spice is everywhere – and then suddenly, it’s gone, replaced almost overnight by peppermint. That scarcity is one of the factors driving the autumnal flavor’s enduring popularity, says Prof. Barbara Kahn in Retail Dive: https://whr.tn/4gYIw2L

Despite its critics and fair share of online mockery, the fact that pumpkin spice-flavored and -scented products are only available for a limited time each year makes it hard for consumers to truly grow tired of it, argues Prof. Kahn.

Additionally, retailers have grown used to the cyclical nature of marketing products, making it easier to reposition seasonal offerings year after year.

Hiroaki (Hiro) Chiba-Okabe, a student in Wharton’s Master of Arts in Statistics and Data Science and a fourth-year doctoral candidate in applied mathematics and computational science in Penn Arts & Sciences, University of Pennsylvania, is exploring the intersection of law and applied math.

Chiba-Okabe, who previously worked in business and international law in Japan, spoke with Penn Today about his work using theoretical models to study questions about social norms, as well as his work with Prof. Weijie Su on generative AI and copyright: https://whr.tn/4eXEQwm

During his studies, he came up with a quantitative metric and algorithm to modify the outputs of generative AI models so they’re less likely to infringe copyright of existing works, an idea he got from legal theory.
